fields.Title of Contribution: Development and calibration of a probabilistic finite element hip capsule representation
fields.Journal: Computer Methods and Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
fields.Description/Abstract: In total hip arthroplasty (THA) patients, excessive laxity of the hip capsule has been related to complications, including wear and dislocation. The objective of this study was to develop a probabilistic representation of the hip capsule, which is calibrated to experimental capsular torque-rotation behavior and captures the observed variability for use in population-based studies. A finite element model of the hip capsule was developed in Abaqus/Explicit. Each structure was composed of a fiber-reinforced membrane, represented by 2D quadrilateral elements embedded with tension-only non-linear spring. The behavior of each structure was defined by structure-specific linear stiffness and reference strain parameters. An average capsule representation was developed by calibrating the properties (linear stiffness, reference strain) of each ligament so that the torque-rotation behavior matched mean data for cadaveric tests. Following calibration, a probabilistic capsule representation was produced by determining the ligament property input variability which resulted in model kinematic variability to represent ± 2 standard deviations as measured in the experiment. For the average model, RMS errors between experimental and model positions at full extension and full flexion were 2.54°. Differences between experimental and model kinematics for all the remaining poses were small with an overall RMS error of 4.70°. Output bounds from the optimized probabilistic capsule representation were consistent with ±2 SD of experimental data; the overall RMS error was 5.10°. This model can be employed in population-based finite-element studies of THA to assess mechanics in realistic scenarios considering implant design, as well as surgical and patient factors.
